newsitem.title: CHINA: China nuclear plant certified for formal operation.
newsitem.headline: China nuclear plant certified for formal operation.

text.p: China's National Nuclear Safety Administration has certified the Daya Bay nuclear power plant in southern Guangdong province for formal operation, the Xinhua news agency said.
The plant, just over the border from the British colony of Hong Kong, was granted certification after a three-year trial commercial operation period, the agency said in a report late on Monday.
The station, outfitted with two 900-megawatt reactors, was China's first nuclear power plant to go into formal operation, Xinhua said.
Workers at the plant had solved problems that touched on safety issues, it said without giving details.
The Daya Bay plant was shut down in March this year when problems with the Unit Two exciter, a non-nuclear component, coincided with the refuelling of the other unit.
A company spokesman then said the defect was not relevant to safety or radioactivity.
Problems with Unit One's reactor control rods while Unit Two was being refuelled forced the shutdown of the plant in April 1995.
A unit of Hong Kong's China Light & Power Co Ltd has a 25 percent stake in the operator of the plant.
Daya Bay's Unit 2 was built by the French state-owned nuclear power group Framatome, in which Alcatel Alsthom owns a substantial stake.
